The position seems to change goals annually and is moving to a more verbal consultative role than actual technical work, almost blending into sales.

job_title: Systems Architect Advisor  in Memphis, TN

cons: As a 24 year veteran, my compensation is not what it should be for the work I do - I chose to not  change companies frequently over the years, which hindered my compensation level.

review_title: I am very experienced at my job and with the policies of FedEx
pros: Your able to move up in the company and change jobs as often as you want.
cons: We are not Union and they are able to take raises away or not give them at all.

pros: Friendly and positive corporate culture; reasonable work-life balance; respect for diversity; job stability; comfortable working environment. It's a great place to work.
cons: As with every corporate job, politics sometimes wins over the best solution, and favoritism can sometimes affect promotions and recognition. Most of the time when managers post a position they already know who they will choose. You can easily get stuck in one area of the company because of your assignments and find you are not able to compete for jobs in another.

review_title: The best transportation Company in the world
pros: The culture of the company is unlike others in the industry. True dedication and involvement from the top down. Great pay and benefits. Career advancement and opportunities based on the a merit system. Respect and concern for the employees. Flexibility in your works schedule. Great perks such as discounts on air travel, retail stores and shops. Great Senior management!! Recognition for a job well done. Constant training opportunities to enhance your ability for other career paths. In closing this company has been around less than 40 years and is by far the best transportation company to work for in Sales.
cons: Some of the internal network issues can hinder the overall performance.

pros: I believe in the company's overall mission and values.
cons:
Managers must be managers and not full time package handlers. Managers need more training (people skills)
At the end of the day, you're so tired it is unreal.

job_title: Senior Disbursement Agent in Memphis, TN
pros:
Fed Ex culture is wonderful. The company gives to charities around the world plus they provide assistance when any disaster occurs.
They have team building activities a few times a year and casual Fridays for employees.
Health care is very affordable and local FedEx Clinics are discounted.
cons: Pay could be a little better and vacation should turn into PTO along with paid holidays and personal days plus sick leave. This would follow other like companies in PTO time instead of qualifying the time off you take.

review_title: Tough job that can be awful beyond belief if you get paired with a bad manager.

cons:
Life work balance is not family friendly.
If you work a M-F shift, you will be forced to work many Saturdays as well. I was working every other Saturday during off peak .

Micromanaging is a daily occurrence. 
The insurance isn't bad but I could never get time off to actually see a doctor for myself or my kids.

 Raises are pretty low - it is difficult to move up in salary without getting promoted.

review_title: Incredible benefits, fair and equitable manangement style.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ

In fact, when I started, everyone I talked to said they suffered an injury and they told me it's inevitable. One guy got heat exhaustion, another said he suffered a concussion.

pros: Good teamwork is a great thing to look forward to on the job, but thats about it. Personal Growth is good on if you consider working their for a few years. Get into management all others jobs are a waste of time if your looking to make some serious money.
cons: Alot of negative things about the job. Peak season is highly frustrating and munch of the lack of effort. Peak season involves the heaviest freight during the city. Peak season is between october and january mostly the holiday season

review_title: Overall it is a good experience, the people I work with are really great and management takes care of its employees.
job_title: Package Handler Part-time in Corpus Christi, TX
pros: A great environment where safety is number one. Job is easy to understand and perform. Team work is fostered at all levels and benefits such as tuition reimbursement are available.
cons: The job requires a lot of lifting and carrying of heavy and awkward objects such as tires and axles. It is in a warehouse type building where cold and heat can seep in. Working around hazardous materials such as containers filled with chemicals and flammable materials.

pros: FedEx is a great place to work if you do drugs and just arent ready to give up that high. Theres plenty of potential to move up and most management is right there with you in the drug use catagory.
cons: Advancing is a long drawn out process (obviosly) because if you intend to show any ambition of moving up, you could be easily used solely for production purposes. They like to pass over people like that, basically leading them on. Its quite frustrating.

job_title: Business Sales Inside Account Executive in Dallas, TX
pros:
The health benefits are very good.

For low-level business sales, the hourly pay rate (about $23/hour) is actually livable. It's not a comfortable living, but you can pay your bills on the base pay, which is nice.

If you want a career in sales and are willing to move, this is a good starting point. Most inside sales reps can promote to field sales in a different city after 15 months, and the pay starts to get more comfortable at that level.

If you enjoy fast-paced, relentless sales, you'll like the job.

Once global travel resumes, you do get to fly standby at decent prices.

When you clock off for the day, you're done. No overtime, no staying late... just carry the stress home with you and let it bubble overnight.
cons:
Career opportunities outside of sales are nearly nonexistent, despite what management will say in your interview. People can move out of sales if they're creative in finding ways to network, which management in the sales office will not be very helpful with.
The path to move up is through field sales. If you're unable to move, or don't want to stay in sales, the best of luck to you.

While the hourly pay is livable, you're unlikely to receive the bonus checks you hear about in the offer letter. 80% of the Dallas office does not bonus for the quarter. It's not a question of work ethic. FedEx is struggling as a company, and it's a very difficult market to be competitive in. Whether or not your territory has potential is luck of the draw.

Since FedEx is doing so poorly right now globally, upper management has put all of its efforts into straining the sales team to do more, constantly. The difficulty of this is exacerbated by the antiquated internal systems that take minutes to hours to struggle through for things like pricing proposals.

The number of sales calls you're expected to make continues to grow to ever more unrealistic levels. While it's possible to make all the calls, emails, and sales opportunities that are expected of you each day, it's unsustainable. I've cycled through my list of customers, some more than once over, in the last month because I'm constantly trying to reach the daily call metric.

If dialing the phone were your only responsibility, it might make sense, but you're also expected to draft pricing proposals and present them to close business. If you spend an hour researching and drafting pricing, and then you spend another hour presenting it, this counts as one sales call in your daily metrics.
According to management, at this point, you've had an extremely unproductive day with your one measly call. Whether or not your time is spent growing revenue is irrelevant.

With such an emphasis on arbitrary daily metrics, there isn't much opportunity to actually do the job you're hired to do, which would be closing business.
All this said, I haven't mentioned how much time it can take to help resolve customer issues. You're constantly told by management to let customer service handle complaints and issues- your job is to sell. Fair enough, but customer service seems to be trained to send customers to their account executive when they aren't sure how to handle something. 

This means that any time you spend not working toward your daily metrics counts as not working. If you're fixing something for a customer, working to create revenue for a company by making proposals, or doing something as important as assisting a teammate with a problem, you are wasting your time in the eyes of management.

There's not enough time in a work day, and there's not enough resources to do the job. All of the complaints I've listed have been discussed with varying levels of management, and are consistently discarded as a personal problem with time management.

TLDR: you're expected to constantly do more, your efforts are hardly appreciated, and when you try to make suggestions for improvement, you're ignored. You feel undervalued as a FedEx employee during these times. The company is struggling, and is trying to get every bit of mileage out of you it can.

I would only recommend this job to someone who lives and breathes selling. Otherwise, this job is not worth the stress.

review_title: FedEx is a pretty good place to work.
job_title: Senior Communications Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: It provides an excellent opportunity to use the communication skills developed over a career in the news business, but without the daily deadline pressure or hurried approach that can impact quality.
cons: There are many layers of management; and it often seems that these people can be working at cross purposes.  Also, because of the structure of the corporation into separate operating companies, communicators working in one area of the company may not be aware of things that are happening in another.  And even though communications and marketing fall under the same umbrella, it's rare to have complete communication between the two groups.

review_title: safe, stable and respectable job in a matured company
job_title: Senior Marketing Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros: work life balance, people service profit philosophy, job security, flexible hours. 360 ddegree feedback is institutionalized across the company and is taken very seriously around here. this keep management honest and committed to the employees.
cons: matured company offers limited growth opportunities. diversity is very visible but promotions are hard to come by. like any big company there is red tape to reckon with, things dont move quickly enough.

review_title: Not a bad place to work.
pros: If you did your work and the boss did not hear of any problems or complaints, you were fine.  Salaries for my line of work were above industry norms.
cons: Having to deal with the compartmented departments.  Groups that needed to work together and communicate did not have a direct channel between them and were under different management organizations.  Groups making decisions that affected others and not telling them or saying-well it's your problem now.

pros: Working in FedEx helps you to better understand the real corporate world. You will be involved in all the meetings of the on going projects in the team. Everybody is so friendly and the living PSP is everywhere around FedEx.
cons: Sometimes team members might be busy with the work they are already assigned with and so are helpless when you need to know something but that remains only for sometime. Later at some point of time, your mentor or your manager will help you finish your objectives assigned during your internship.

review_title: You can learn a great deal & work with great people but don't expect a decent raise or high pay based on job performance
job_title: Customer Service, Customs Brokerage in Seattle, WA
pros: If you push to learn a lot, you will be given the opportunity to learn a lot. You will work with other very professional and dedicated people in a very complex industry. You will receive public recognition for a job well done. Good benefits, retirement and health care package. They actually do a pension plan and most companies don't anymore. You can move around within the company in different roles if you want to. They are rapidly growing and are at the forefront of technology used with US CBP. This attracts big companies that do international business to desire a working relationship with Fedex Trade Networks leading to increased business opportunities.
cons: Just because you learn a lot, or are extremely good at your job doesn't mean you will get a pay increase. You can be awesome at your job, do a ton of work and be extremely productive and the person next to you can be lazy and unproductive, you will both be paid the same. Even though you receive public recognition for achievements, that doesn't result in better pay or bonuses. Several years ago Fedex Trade Networks did this but now they do not anymore due to their goal of ORGANIC growth. I.E. encourage hard work in employees, pay them low wages, grow the company and pad corporate executives pockets with bonuses and stock options. The benefits are great but the pay won't help you pay down school debt any faster. Moving around within the company doesn't guarantee salary increases, just more work.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Henderson, NV
pros: Best reasons are working for a company that values there employees and as long as they are willing to move up. Depends how deep down and high spirited towards the job they appreciates. Will succeed within the company in any position.
cons: Not hardly but there are always an added improvements to provide FedEx the best in its field.

pros: The job is easy - you can literally finish your day of work within your first 3 hours.
cons: You will get screwed out of literally every bonus. Accounts are aligned based on one person on Memphis and if you find that an account that shouldn't be yours is negatively affecting you, they don't care. You can fix it for 6 months from now but have to eat it for 2 quarters. Also, management is completely clueless.

pros: Mgmt for Fedex pls read
cons: Mgmt Fedex pls read employee scamming system CB.

job_title: Project Management Analyst in Collierville, TN
pros:
My position at FedEx Services as a Project Management Analyst has been incredible. Benefits? Incredible. Work-Life Balance? Incredible. Culture? Incredible. The management team has been kind, supportive, consistent, fair,  intelligent and dependable. In less than a year, I have had 3 managers (my hiring manager, the organization re-org'd after providing a buyout, and then my manager moved over to fill a hard-to-fill management spot to allow an individual contributor to move up) . All three managers have been as I described above. FedEx in general gives you all the tools to do your job properly. They live the People-Service-Profit culture, and you have an army of people willing to help if you need it. VP & Director communication is impressive. And while I'm excited about my promotion to Express, I am sad to part Services and this wonderful organization. 

As far as the physical environment, the cubicles are neat and consistent. Large with a decent amount of filing space. The buildings are shaped in a circular fashion, where all of the backs face each other, and out of the back door, you have a large park area where there is patio furniture, walking trail, and just beautiful, serene area if you need it. One of the buildings has an immaculate gym. They also have a cafeteria of sorts which has a standard hot and cold sandwich place, awesome salad bar, 2 soups, and then one 'guest' spot where companies like Chick-Fil-A come in.
cons: Everything I could possible list on here, FedEx has a plan to upgrade or eliminate.

review_title: Responsible for product management, defining and implementing product/services initiatives

job_title: Truck Driver in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good benifits. 401k. Pension. Non Union. Medical,  Dental, Vision available.  Most employees great people. They just want to do their job and go home to family.
cons: Pay increases should be on performance not years of service. How well you are treated comes down to your manager. Some senior managers are abusive and will use a willing manager to make all of the employees lives miserable and no one above will help if the numbers are good. Yes. They knew.

pros: Salary, lots of unusual benefits, tech forward.  Reliable, solid company.  Don't believe in cutting workers unless absolutely necessary.  Profit sharing for those not on commission based salary is great when the market is up.
cons: Mobility is almost impossible if you don't live in Memphis, TN. Unless you live close to world HQ, or are very willing to relo, it's almost impossible to move up within the company.  Upper management is out touch.  Lots of RahRah management speak, but reality doesn't come close to what they preach.  Very much in the box....

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Memphis, TN
pros: Health Benefits package is more affordable then my previous place of employment. I have Sundays off which is a plus because I attend church in Sundays. I enjoy learning something new about transportation and warehouse everyday that I am here. Not sure how much longer I will be working here because of the hours.
cons: Must work from the bottom for a year before you can advance to a better paying position coming in the door. The physical labor is challenging at 52 years of age.

pros: Great Team environment and learning experience on how to receive and ship packages.
cons: The company tries hard not to give overtime even if you worked over hours in a day because it got too busy. They will have you come in later or leave earlier so you don't go over 40 hours for the week. Upper Management is not honest and they will choose who to put in leadership position based on favoritism instead of experience or training. This had made me decide to leave FedEx in the near future and work for someone else.

review_title: FedEx is an excellent company to work for!
job_title: Senior Project Analyst in Collierville, TN
pros: For me, FedEx has been a fantastic company to work for.  I've been with FedEx for 2.5 years after running my own business and have really enjoyed the structure, pay, benefits and attitude with regard to work/life balance.  It has been a great move.
cons: FedEx is a very large corporation and you do run into bureaucray in your day to day work.

pros: Pay is great for only being a part-time job. Benefits are also very stellar for only being PT. Once you prove yourself, management is very willing to work with you.
cons: My only complaint has been of management lately at my facility. Someone was hired based on who they were and not what they knew. Now morale is down at our facility from being micromanaged by someone who does not really know what is going on.

pros: pride in the brand, benefits are good especially travel perks; should be more to say but cant really think of anything else; tuition reimbursement is great
cons: too metrics focused. not focused enough on the people; constant pressure to do more and they don't seem to value experience anymore. very focused on new people. definitely not interested in using the right people for the right jobs. continuing to downsize through attrition just to hide what you are doing is not working. Pressuring people by having them do 3 and 4 people's job is wrong.

job_title: Senior ECO Import Agent in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
You know what you're going to be doing all day, every day.  No surprises.  It's set up to be like a data entry job.  If you are content to turn yourself into a robot for 9 hours a day, then this job is perfect for you.  After moving to a position involving wildly varying pace, uncertainty, and anxiety, I miss this sometimes.

Good vacation benefits.  Medical benefits used to be good, but were getting severely cut around the time I left.
cons:
Boring isn't a strong enough word to describe the work.  I had days where even after 9 hours of sleep the night prior, I would still have to struggle so hard to stay awake that it was physically painful.  The environment is horribly stale.  Quiet.  No decorations.  The work experience is a drudgery grind.

And this would be fine, if employees were allowed to engage in periodic distraction.  A glance at something on the web now and then is enough to keep the brain awake.  Consider also that you're given hard metrics on productivity, so it really shouldn't be a problem if you stay within them.

But no distractions of any kind are officially permissible except for listening to music through headphones.  Doing absolutely anything else with your time while in the office provokes politics.  You could produce the highest numbers in the office and then get in trouble for being unproductive for 10 minutes - not exaggeration, this literally happened.

The regional manager is also horribly obsessive-compulsive - once demanding that my co-worker put his monitor in the same position on his desk as everyone else on the cubicle block, even though doing so aggravated his carpal tunnel.  

The politics are ridiculous.  Favoritism runs deep and rampant.  Upper management will create rules just to bully and micromanage certain employees they don't like, while nothing is enforced on others.  Most of the favorites were people who were barely productive, and spent most of their time trying to get productive employees in trouble for sport.  And the excessively detailed rules created the perfect environment for bullying to take place.

There was one clique in particular who produced the lowest numbers in the office, worked several hours of overtime every day even during periods where anybody else would get written up for clocking out 1 minute past 8 hours, and they would pick on people relentlessly.  They would rotate targets for harassment, and take turns walking past their target's desk periodically to see what they were doing.  If it was anything other than focusing exclusively on work, they would immediately complain, and that person would get written up.  This was an ongoing state of affairs for all 7 years I worked in that office.

Also, any communication regarding pay or the value of your work from corporate was always extremely insulting.  Best example:  there is a fundraising drive every year for United Way.  Every year they show a promotional video.  One year, they had one of the company's top executives introduce the video by saying "We're all feeling the effects of the economic recession", while wearing his immaculate suit and politician's smile.  They then proceeded to show a little documentary bit about how *one of our own co-workers* didn't make enough money to take care of her kid, and how United Way helped her to make ends meet.  And then asked us to donate...

job_title: Hub Operatins Manager in Memphis, TN
pros: FedEx is a great company to work for compared to other companies because of the higher pay rate and the decent benefits. Now they do expect hard labor and favoritism is around but it's like that at all jobs.. They off better pay than most jobs around now so I would say it is a win.
cons: The hours of work would cause me to stay asleep all night simply so I can make it to work on time. You have to be disciplined at managing your schedule and your work life.

review_title: Great place to work, with limited advancement opportunities.
pros: Great people, decent benefits, lots of opportunity for development. FedEx is a great training ground to learn and develop skills.
cons: Old boys club, limited opportunities for advancement, not very progressive with maternity/paternity leave or vacation. It is hard to advance in to management. Management seems to take for granted the high performers and don't seem concerned about providing opportunities for high performs. To much focus on seniority.

review_title: Company will do anything for its clients, must also focus on its staff more.
pros: Good team of colleagues. bad coffee, good internal learning program
cons: to many managers who look up, and forget to look down to the workers, all the time budget cuts work with FedEx now for more than 12 years. all extra bonus and or Employee Benefits are cut back, or shut down over a period of 10 years now. this crisis will not help to improve these bonus or benefits back soon.

pros: Great paid time off and cheap health insurance.
cons: Bad management, poor communication, HR doesn't do HR functions, turnover is at an all time high, morale is at an all time low, new people don't have a desk to sit at when they get out of training, there is nowhere to park, brand new employees start out making more than employees who have been with the company for more than 5 years.

pros: Decent pay, especially if you’re topped out.  The hourly pay depends on where you work.  Higher cost of living areas pay more.  As long as people shop on the internet there will always be job security.   Shipping discount.  Ability to transfer to other cities.
cons: Sometimes erratic hours as operational needs are foremost.   Long days not good for young families, as you will miss all after school events.  Your pay and progression is based solely on your seniority, not by your efforts or merits.

review_title: Could be very stressful and busy or too easy  some days.
pros: Very affordable health insurance for an employee, if needed. Some possibilities of growing within.  Advantage of college education.
cons:
Impossible to survive, if have no other support.  The yearly raise would be even more shocking, , < 1%!) Better have not even'd been offered, as it just hurts.
Driving consumes 1/3 of what you make (gas, car insurance, etc). Benefits are good if you are in bad health, elder and use insurance a lot, otherwise, no need. The luck of proper training materials. In someone's absence do their jobs for the same salary.

review_title: It could be worse, but it could always be better
job_title: Senior Technical Analyst in Collierville, TN
pros: FedEx has the ability to pull up its bootstraps when times get difficult.  I have seen management continually cut costs, thus ensuring the workforce is spared from layoffs.  In a time when job security is somewhat scarce, FedEx has continually offered its workforce a safe haven as long as packages keep shipping.  I believe this is a testament to the overall management by our founder Fred Smith.  As long as he is around, I really do believe the employees will be thought about before drastic cuts are made.
cons: There are a lot of "old guard" employees left at FedEx.  The same benefit that FedEx has in providing a safe haven for its employees, also leads to a bit of a downfall in unqualified workers.  In the IT arena where I work, there are many folks still on the job, whether having moved to a new department or not, whose time had come many years ago.  Unfortunately, it seems neither they nor management has seen it that way.  It leads to discourse in some of the younger and hungrier employees who share the same titles as the older ones, but end up performing most of the work.  These "old-timers", whose vacation times now exceed 5 weeks in some cases, come and go as they please, and are allowed to reap the same benefits and titles as those of us with much more aptitude for the job.  This can be very discouraging and cause a lot of qualified folks to turn away from working at FedEx.

review_title: Kinko's is off the name and sadly it looks more and more like a sign of things to come
pros: Decent pay, great shipping discount, many locations worldwide, opportunity to learn a great deal about printing, computers and shipping.
cons:
Systematically they have removed all the old Kinko's upper management.  
Way too focused on immediate profit rather than growing the customer base. 
Stores are understaffed and employees are overworked.
All of the creativity and innovation has been quashed and replaced with corporate mandates.

job_title: Senior Technical Specialist in Collierville, TN
pros:
You're rarely expected to work long hours, unless something blows up.
Fairly competitive salaries in an inexpensive location.
Keep your head down and your mouth shut and you'll likely stay employed, unless you just happen to be selected in the next layoff lottery.
Great place to work if you're female or a minority; corporate policies are very vigilant about discrimination due to race, gender, sexual orientation, etc.
cons:
Morale is pretty bad these days, given recent layoffs (which seemed pretty random) and last year's pay cuts. Lots of corporate Rah! Rah! marketing programs, emails, posters which for most of us actually are very counter-productive. For the 12th time in 13 years FedEx was voted in Forbes' Top 100 Places to Work. The primary reason given that FedEx is so fantastic: this year we get back half of the 401K match they took away with our pay cuts last year. They had just beefed up the match the year before to compensate us for ditching the pension!

Depending on where you work, you may be plagued with endless meetings. Very often meetings are held not to get input from participants but to disseminate information that could be easily distributed with an email.

There is little room for advancement, in particular technical advancement. The Advisor positions which were created years back might have been used for a more advanced technical position, at least in technical groups, but they are primarily political in nature. Every 'Principal' position - the highest level non-management job - was filled by the buddy system, which is rampant in my particular org.

There is a bit of a hivemind here, and individual thinkers are unlikely to prosper. Incompetent and toeing the party line will get you farther than making waves for improvement. Mediocrity is rewarded, while innovative thinking is a crapshoot.

There are way too many corporate initiatives, and the company is forever paying some consulting firm gadzillions of dollars to recommend one or the other course of action, but we rarely have follow-through. It keeps these initiatives from doing any real harm, but it wastes a lot of resources along the way.

pros: stable place to work, systems work, great name, founder is still CEO
cons: very unhappy people working here.  management has gone down hill and could care less if you stay or go.  not supportive....  overall, the work isn't bad or very complicated.  a little mundane and there is NO room for any outside the box thought.  nothing fun or progressive going on here

review_title: The place to work in Memphis
pros:
Every employee is treated as a vital and valued part of the organization. 
Outstanding opportunity for advancement and career development even for people lacking a college degree or traditional education.
Training readily available for carrer development.  
Company culture values military veterans and the experience gained in service to the military.
Very good benefits, even for part time and non-exempt employees. 
Company is a steward to the community and encourages employees to follow the example
cons:
Expect to work hard in the sort facility. It is tough work but strong teams are built to handle it. 
24/7/365 operation. Expect long hours and little time off in the Holiday rush.

review_title: Solid company- they expect you to want to build a career there.
pros: Stability- you won't make a mint but you can be pretty certain if you do your job you will continue to have one.  Good organizational culture with a sense of humor.  There are some people
cons: Lots of internal barriers to promotion and movement- some cultural some legal.  Things take time, and it can be difficult to see results from your work in the short term.

pros: Has some of the smartest people I've ever met working there. Large IT campus in Memphis has walking trails, a nice cafeteria, wooded grounds, secure parking.
cons: They drive the better people so hard that all but the most masochistic leave. Many that work there do the bare minimum to keep their jobs. Management is more political than Washington. Projects are a morass of constrictive processes involving lots of departments and meddling, yet you are expected to deliver big.

pros:
Benefits are very good, especially for part time employees: tuition refund, health, dental and 401k. 
Service FedEx provides to its customers is bar none.
cons: Upper management's ability to prioritize projects is lacking. Projects are added to the list, even when the business justification is not there to support it. This causes projects to have schedules that last years instead of months because there is not enough staff to complete the work in a reasonable amount of time. Additionally, scope creep is an issue (again at upper mgmt level). Company culture has changed. FedEx, at one time, really valued their employees, unfortunately this is no longer the case.

review_title: Good first step on the career path
pros: Good total compensation package, when benefits and vacation time are considered. Good training and experience that is sought after outside of FTN.
cons: Rapid growth about a decade ago led to many underqualified/borderline incompetent individuals being promoted to middle management positions. These individuals are now in a career parking pattern and obstructing the advancement of many very talented and motivated individuals below them.  Things are beginning to sort themselves out, but in the meanwhile the company is bleeding talent and slowly filling itself with the wrong kind of "lifers."

review_title: Better employer than most, old-style management
pros: Good benefits, good perks, one of the few companies that still have pensions, good bonuses
cons: Old-style management, emphasis on seniority, sometimes challenging to move up, non-union, H/R is elusive to employees by design, no open-door policy

review_title: Great benefits....the people policy is declining.
pros: Good pay, good benefits. Extensive training. Holiday pay, sick pay, vacation pay, and floating as need off pay days. Opportunity for advancement and transfers. Free air travel.
cons: Upper management has begun to micromanage since 2008. This has resulted in less teamwork and more focus on individual performance. Work hours can be long and there's very little flexibility to take time off in emergency situations...sick child, etc. You have to bid on vacation time once a year, senior employees get first choice leaving crappy options for newer employes.

pros: Relax don't do anything environment
cons: Baby boomer management should retire by now but still driving technology and still believe in storage using tapes. Too many offshore faces who can't even speak understandable English. Only way to become a manager is either you cook good Indian food or know how to boot lick your Director. Project Managers are the most incompetent jerks and marketing team can only sell used cars.

review_title: Working at World HQ (corporate office) in Memphis
pros: Although it's not what it used to be before the company became so enormous, the culture here is generally very good. People are friendly, teams generally work well together and upper management works hard to reinforce the importance of collaboration and team spirit. Pays very well for Memphis--- it's so cheap to live here that you can buy a house on pretty much any salaried position. World HQ is a pretty campus next to a golf course with trees, a lake, a walking trail, big cafeteria overlooking the golf course, and a fitness center. Employees receive discounts on shipping and with certain companies like Dell and AT&T. Health benefits are competitive, there's a 401K, and there is still a lump-sum pension benefit as of 2014.
cons: FedEx is actually not just a single company--- it's a group of operating companies that "operate independently, compete collectively". Despite efforts to overcome it, there is still a tendency toward "silos" and being territorial at all levels. Having personnel headquarters in Memphis has become an increasing liability since it is a decaying city with a lot of crime, ineffective leadership, high property and sales tax rates, terrible traffic and failing public schools. The great majority of employees are here because they're either from here or they have ties here (family nearby, etc), they are careful about where they buy a home, and they are willing to fork over the money to send their kids to private schools. This could be a good place for a young, childless person, especially someone interested in the arts, to put in two or three years but overall, this is not a particularly innovative or nimble company; there's a lot of "this is how we've always done it".

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Fort Worth, TX
pros: They make sure their employees are well taken care of. You work alone, the shifts are short. No micromanagement and the managers are laid back and easy going.
cons: The work is a little fast paced. It's not an easy job, but it's more of you having to get use to lifting heavy boxes and playing tetris. It gets really hot in the trailers and the pay is worth it. Not that many people to talk to.

review_title: Part Time pay with Full Time expectations.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The possibility of moving into other positions
cons: The unrealistic expectations for $200.00

job_title: Driver Trainer in Milton Keynes, England
pros: Fedex is the best company i have ever worked for they are a forward think company. I have come from LGV driver to driver trainer and been supported all the way by my manager and the whole of the transport team. FedEx is a great place to work we do team work.
cons: As far as i am  concerned there are no cons this is a GREAT company  with Great people working together to make FedEx the number 1 in the world (which i think we are)

review_title: I Feel Very Lucky To Work For FedEx!!!! Great Company!!!!
job_title: Inside Sales Account Executive in Irving, TX
pros: Competitive Pay, Great Benefits, Great Opportunities Domestically and Globally, Selling the FedEx Brand, Job Security, Great Work Environment, Great Training and the way that your treated and coached by management (Developmental, Supportive, Fair and Objective)
cons: Working with individuals who don’t appreciate the company or who do not want to pull their weight. Negative people always bring me down. However, for the most part all of the Account Executives I work with are exceptional and very professional. But like every company/sales department there are always individuals who struggle and are negative because of it.

review_title: If you're a courier...get ready to eat hours
pros: Different couriers all working together to get the work done.
cons: Read "Independent Contractor (Current Employee) Florence, KY". Very helpful insight as to the roots of the problem at FedEx - they have ******completely**** you could say "washed their hands clean" of driving responsibility by pushing everything onto contractors...but then stopped compensating them for everything. Belts have been tightened at every step. You're not compensated for your time AT ALL, most every location pays couriers PER DAY, so if you're out 15 hours, your pay is god-awful and possibly below min. wage depending on where you live.

job_title: Fed Ex Courier in Boston, MA
pros:
benefits for part-time were good.  When you were on the road you are pretty much left alone.
management does recognize good work and will document such.
cons:
stressful to meet time deadlines when you can only drive so fast.
on days when there were less stops the avg stops per hour will obviously correlate to that.  so mgmt will tell you that you need to improve on that.  no way to do that unless there are more stops which you cannot have control of that.  
Some managers better than others.

pros: Company that allows growth, and easy to move up in the company. Have learned that your experience will greatly depend on your senior manager. Easy to transfer, or move to a different location and have a job. Benefits. better pay than retail. Get to be on the move. More often than not, management started same place as you.
cons: Your experience depends on management, if you don't like the company it's probably their faught and best just to transfer elsewhere.

pros: FedEx is a fast paced environment and there is always something new to learn.  Pay is good on years where the bonus is good, but the bonus isn't guaranteed even if you meet all your yearly goals for your particular building.
cons: Annoying internal audit procedures that cost more time than the actual operations.  Managers are expected to be on call 24/7 and working on vacation is encouraged.  In the northeast most higher ups are bullies who will yell at you constantly and tell you to fix things without guidance on how to do so.  You are expected to learn and implement everything yourself.

review_title: Corporations with "staying power" evolve with the times.
pros: Benefits are the best reason.  Salary is adequate as well.
cons: Internal politics are a bit of a challenge, especially when there is a major "changing of the guard" at the top

review_title: Be on the good side of your superiors.  This will open opportunities down the road.
job_title: Dock Worker in Grove City, OH
pros: benefits,  tuition reimbursement.  Great part time job for students.
cons: If you're out of shape, this will suck for the first month.   It does get a lot easier the longer you're there.

pros: Job until you find a better one.
cons: Went out of their way to remove employees who had full term benefits,pensions,sick pay, in order to bring in outsiders at a lessor pay and benefits. This is a normal tactic or practice at this company, and to harrass and follow employees to further terrorize them....Go to U.P.S and save yourself the years of wasted time and aggravation....

review_title: 12 years as a swing courier has been a constantly evolving experience.
pros: No chance to get bored at this job! Good pay and benefits. Physically demanding, so less time at the gym. No layoff policy (even throughout the recession). Many opportunities for career advancement and able to transfer anywhere in the world if there is a position open.
cons: Sometimes long hours and Saturday work required. Physically demanding. Productivity expectations are sometimes unreasonable. Fast pace and covering different areas is not for everyone.

review_title: Great company to work for as a pilot
pros: Excellent pay and benefits for the industry. Stable, no furloughs in the history of the company, as far as pilots go. First class operation, airplanes are well maintained, flight safety is top priority. Tremendous amount of flexibility for this kind of job, as far as how much you desire to work.
cons: Much of our flying is at night, which is very difficult on your body. Possible exposure to hazardous goods in a confined area. Don't know if they ever clean out the oxygen system for the masks, which could make you sick. These issues make me concerned about getting cancer.

review_title: My experience has been disappointing, and not what I expected from a Fortune 500 company.
pros: Large company, good benefits including pension plan, and leadership series' webinars.
cons: Low salary, no work flexibility for long distance commuting, jobs with unclear roles and responsibilities, and managers who have no real skills to be in these positions.  There is a lot of nepotism that exists here, which makes for an unhealthy and toxic work environment.

review_title: FedEx is resting on its laurals, but is still a go company to work for.
pros: FedEx still has many of the benefits that other companies have thrown away, although not as "rich" as they use to be.  FedEx Express has never laid off an employee.  FedEx promotes very largely from within.  FedEx treates customers much better than others in industry and therefore has a brand that gives an employee clout.  Most employees get along with each other and work together.
cons:
There is the "FedEx way" and the wrong way.  This manifests itself in Purple-Correct thinking.  The company doesn't take serious ideas that come from "outsiders" who are hired.  Your opinion is valued inverse proportially to the number of digits in your employee number.  Except for Fred Smith, no one above the rank of Sr. VP understands the airline part of the company, so airline type issues do not get priority except in the view of eliminating cost.  Also, since the company has never laid off any workers, there are a lot of dead weight leeches entrenched inside the company.  Lot of people doing their nails in their cubes and taking 20 minute smoke breaks each hour.

Finally, if the company's salary exempt pay structure is near immoral.  No adjustment for cost of living.  Merit increases cap at 3.5% for a 4.0 employee.  This causes talented employees to leave while the leaches stay on.

pros: Worklife balance, low cost of living in memphis, Fortune 500 company, one of the best brands, most admired companies in the world. You are not expected to put in more than 40 hours of work each week and do get fabulous discounts with retailers/restaurants in memphis
cons: If you are looking for career path and career growth, management typically looks down on people with initiative and aggressive career goals. They mostly want followers and people who follow them blindly without asking any questions.. Middle management has limited leadership capabilities and minimal business skills.

review_title: FEDEX IS CHANGING! IT IS THE COMPANY OF YESTERDAY! THE ORGANIZATION NO LONGER VALUES THEIR EMPLOYEES
job_title: Inside Sales Account Executive in Tampa, FL
pros:
FedEx was a great place to work.  When I came to work for this company, I truly believed that it was an organization that cared about their employees.  I thought it was a company where I could advance, grow and use the full range of my educational abillities.  Unfortunately, after working for the company for almost 5 years,  I have discovered that things are changing greatly at FedEx.   FedEx is not a company that cares about their employees.  I understand that the economic conditions are impacting this organization. However, I was very disappointed when the news revealed that I would be receiving a pay deduction before I was aware. To make matters worse, I opened an e-mail to read about the changes that would be effective immediately. I had to call my manager for clarification. This information was not proactively provided to me.  What a disappointment? Did the company care about me? I wanted notification so that I could make the necessary adjustments and pay. To add insult to injury, the press release said that the pay deduction would be permenant and I would not receive a merit increase in 2009.  I would be a little more accepting if the company was committed to bringing me back up to the my current salary level after the economic situation improves. There was no commitment.  Health insurance costs continue to increase as well.

I cannot think of a good reason to work for FedEx, now.
cons: If you are working as a Field Account Executive, you are in a deadend career. There are very few promotion opportunities until you know someone or play the "kiss your- you know what" game. Educations, sales success - it does not really matter. Also, the requirements of even advancing to the next grade level is nearly impossible.

review_title: Just  my observation - but shared by so many grunts who bleed purple.
job_title: Technical Principal in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Flex Time and Bonuses were good.  But the greatest reason to work for FedEx is the people (non-management).  They are the most down earth set of people you could work with.
cons:
FedEx's Low Level Managment to the CIO lack vision and direction, despite management's propaganda.  Many of FedEx Services problems are the reflection of the leadership in the management chain.  It's not what you know but who you know.  But this mantra has caught up to FedEx as it eventually catches up to most companies.  Middle management is more concerned with climbing up the corporate chain than doing what is right for the company, the stockholders, or the employees.  The Executive Management is so out of touch with was occurring at FedEx Services because they rely on middle management to be concise, ethical, and to the point.  However, as most work places including FedEx Services, middle management tells senior management what they want to hear rather than tell them how it really is. 

If you don't believe my commentary.  Ask a FedEx Services employee how successful 6x6 or 6x6 Reloaded was/is (off the record) in Memphis, Dallas, Colorado Springs, and Orlando?  For the brave souls who bleed purple will tell you it was/is a joke.  The biggest joke is the CIO, the Senior Vice Presidents, and the Vice Presidents, the most useless executives that the FedEx subsidiary could have assembled.  This management team should be dismantled and rebuilt.   Managing Directors and Managers should be terminated for three consecutive poor Pulse Survey Reviews.

My respect lies with the Chief Executive Officer like Fred W. Smith and Chief Financial Officer (CFO) Alan Graf and the grunts (Software Developers, Network Operations, Technical Writers, Networking Groups) within FedEx Services.  Everyone else is expendable.

pros: easy to get hired.  They provide pay to get your commercial driver's license (CDLs).  Free uniforms.  Recognizeble employer that provides good resume experience.  Get exercise while working.
cons: little control over number of hours you're working.  Frequently log 50+ hours.  Blue collar mentality.  Sometimes you feel under-appreciated.

review_title: Great company, managers can make or break career
pros: Nationally recognized name, known product.
cons: Some managers want you to pull blood from a rock. Culture of the business allows customers to switch to a competitor at anytime. No one knows exactly how compensation works. You could have a great quarter or a bad one...it all depends on how your goals are set and the "behind-the-scenes" calculations that go on. Work/life: not out of the ordinary to do admin work until 9-10pm. Almost expected.

review_title: I loved the job except numbers were more important that customer service.
pros: You can interact with different people everyday.  You are in your own truck all day without supervision most of the time.  You get a good workout while you work.  Time passes quickly because your always running to meet deadlines.  I never got bored because your too busy.  I got satisfaction by helping my customers. Pay and benefits were excellent.
cons: There is too much micro management while your in the station unloading and loading the freight.  We were pressures do always do more with less people.  Too much paperwork and goal to meet in numbers on paper.  Getting 100% wasnt good enough.  Get written up for the smallest thing.  They had unreasonable expectations with delivery and pickup stops per hour.  without considering traffic or distance between stops.  Had to work over 12 hours a day but managment expected you to only put down 12 hours and not be paid because DOT laws.  Always had to work 10 to 12 hours without any break just to meet their unrealistic goals.  I was told to loose customers who were filling my truck up with freight and to replace them with 10 customers shipping 1 package because it made the managers numbers look better and they got bigger bonuses. They would promise us big bonuses to get us to work harder and faster and work thru breaks and on our own time but when the time came would make some excuse why the company couldn't pay it. They thought we should just be thankful to have the jib because other people don't,  But the managers would get 12,000 bonuses for our hard work.  If you got hurt they were out to get rid of you because they could lose some of their monthly bonuses. Managers showed too much favortism.

pros:
International company with reasonable benefits. 
Training program includes videos, manuals, tests and buddy training. 
Good people to work with and Saskatoon has a very nice facility.
Saskatoon management team was eager to help you succeed.
cons:
My biggest surprise and perhaps disappointment is that the technology the company uses is so antiquated. For most people, looking up addresses on a map can be tedious and time consuming. When you are new, that is the way it is done.

Try to imagine doing this manual look up for 70-100 packages/envelopes a day and then trying to frame that into a route/run where you are minimizing (or trying to minimize) the amount of time you spend doubling back on yourself. Of course, if you have a regular route, over the weeks and months you will improve in this regard but for someone new it is almost tragic. 

I am sure that eventually they will incorporate more GPS and the morning sorts and truck set-ups will carry a higher degree of automation but for now things are firmly embedded in the early 1990's.

No coffee breaks, very easy to miss lunch breaks when busy.

pros: Great company, believe in People, Service, and Profits.. In the order. Very active in the local community and throughout the world, I am proud too say that I worked for FedEx.
cons: They have high level of expectations and  create some stressful situations. Also moving away from remote workers, while the rest of the world moves towards remote workers, FedEx is moving away from remote workers

pros: Great Company to work for flexalbe hours good pay with no experience I've only been working with the company over 3 months but I hope to grow with this company.
cons: It is not the cleanest environment It is very fast paste I don't feel like I have been trained enough to do my job.

pros: The fedex health benefits are fantastic and is one of the two reasons I stay with the company because they offer fulltime benefits to part time employees like me. The 2nd reason I stay with the company is to be able to transfer to other states with the company and work and live in a new place.
cons: Communication is terrible and getting help with different parts of the job is next to none from my manager. The pay is not the greatest either...very demanding and can be a high stress job. Must be able to be quick and multitask.

job_title: Senior Aircraft Mechanic in Memphis, TN
pros: Beats being homeless,good pay,job security.
cons: Retirement just cash pension, Health benefits inadequate,Retiree healthcare $1,000 per mon. work rules change daily, things are so bad we are in the middle of an organizing drive to have the Teamsters represent us in Aircraft Maint. We WILL get a CONTRACT.This Co. has gone from being A place that once held strong to the PSP philosophy(people,service,profit),now its all about the profit and keeping Wallstreet happy.

review_title: Great place to work for people whp are not high acheivers

review_title: Great benefits for part time work
job_title: Dangerous Goods Agent in Reno, NV
pros: Health benefits for part time employees.  The pay is comparable to competitors such as UPS.  Stable company with great brand recognition.
cons: Managers lack training on how to effectively deal with employees.  Many of middle management has been with Fed Ex for a long time and may not have the best skills or managment tools, but a good grasp of the business.

job_title: Human Resources Professional in Collierville, TN
pros: Promotional opprtunities are available althought the descriptions of the Jobs may not be exactly what the managers are looking for.
cons: In the smaller niche groups such as HR a preconvienced opinion of others could ruin ones career. When in larger groups - such as IT, Marketing and Solutions this would not be a factor.

pros: Fedex uses good routing and scanner technology to help navigate your area. And, when on the road you curtail it to work best for you. Meet interesting customers and working for a high profile company. Hard work but overall you will have a good business.
cons: You work with a contractor first not with fedex. And, if and when a route becomes available you may be considered. You may have long days and truck/van breakdowns and are responsible for any losses.

pros: Loved my job for most of the 23 yrs I was there. It used to be a family now its not anymore. I was a Courier. Loved my customers.
cons: They don't care about the people its all about the numbers and micro managing. Its very sad...If undercover boss ever came to a station they would be shocked. Its not the company it used to be :(

pros: Benefits, co-workers, 401k and pension.
cons: There is no work, life, balance. You need to work 10 hour sales days and do your admin work after that so its more of a 12 hour day. Very little corporate support. They give you all kinds of initiatives but very little support for it. Don't ever work in the BSF position.

review_title: Get out while you still can...
pros: EASY work...does not require a lot of brain power.  The hardest park about the job is just getting the motivation to come in on a daily basis and dealing with bad weather.
cons: Working with a bunch of people that are as lazy as I've ever seen and a company that expects you to keep learning additional skills and processes without any kind of reward or pay raise.  If you like working for a company that won't give you a raise for years at a time and new hires that make within $1.00/hr of employees that have been with the company for a decade, than FedEx is your company.

pros: Great benefits and some of the great people to work with!
cons: Hard working employees are never recognized by the management. Managers take all the credit for their team members work and management doesn't make an effort to find and reward the people who do the actual work. Also in their zealousness to encourage diversity, they discard and disregard people who have been working with them for years, just because their fault is they belong to the "Majority" so there is a culture of rewarding someone from a different background even though that person is a non-performing member.

review_title: Profitable Organization - Culture Suffers from Over OutSourcing.

People - Service - Profit philosophy?  When you have to teach people how to act something is missing.

review_title: Worked as a package handler. Hot warehouse work but not difficult.
job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Kennesaw, GA
pros: Instead of paying for a gym, work at a package warehouse and get an overall workout and get paid. Hours are short, 3 to 4 tops a day but there is always a chance to pick up another shift.
cons: Very hot, sometimes dirty. Minimal pay and short hours equal small checks. Everyone begins at the bottom and goes up from there. Much better environment and culture than UPS.

pros: A good company overall according to research. A few perks as far as flying standby and vendor discounts, part time employees offered benefits same as full time, no brain required. If you are basically desperate for a little extra cash and can tolerate the belittling; it’s a definite paycheck every week.
cons: As far as this specific facility >>>Literally plantation/slavery work. house “people” that have been there and titled as “team leaders” stand around watching and dictating as you’re busting your butt. Demeaning.

job_title: Air Craft Material Handler in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent company to work and some of the people there are very friendly and helpful and kind. The peoples that work at Fedex are team work and we help each other.  Good company to work for.
cons: In one prtectler and one department call Input weekend shift, the teamleader she didn't treat some of the new employee fair and equal. And she treat one person better then other person better than other one in there. (Favoritiasom)

review_title: You just dont hear the negative, that doesnt mean it's that great of a place - good spin doctors at FedEx.
pros:
Fiscally aware and will enforce pay cuts vs. laying off.
Benefits are decent.
cons:
Political.  Not much standardization for the sales force i.e., a type of sink or swim environment with tools flying at us that are not properly tested before we get them.  These take up time we dont have but are required to use, only to have the next new thing be dumped on us a few weeks later.  It is like a contest to see who can make a name for themselves by coming up with a new technique and after that we have to work out the bugs.  By that time, another tool or training will be required.      We supposedly are given warm leads, but approx 40% of the spreadsheet are companies out of business, havent shipped in over 10 years, etc.  To close the sale we have to use a process, which means if a customer wants to ship with us the same day we call, we cannot close it unless we have a minimum of 3 calls.  AND we have to move the sale through a "certainty' rating, which means  we have to log the close as 25% sure, then 50% sure, then 75%, 90% then close it.   Many dont do it this way and just make sure they have the minimum 3 calls.  No one seems to believe that an inside sasales professional can know if the customer is wanting to ship in one or 2 calls.  Also, we now have a phone system that allows management to listen to our calls so there is the Big Brother aspect.  

Managers play favorites and there is no recourse to this as the manager network is tight.  I.e., it would do no good to report one as blatantly applying the rules according to their personal preferences vs. what is fair and equitable.  

The sales job requires a minutia of extraneous tasks in additional to actual selling.  The systems we have are not user friendly and it requires using 4-5 places to find all the information necessary to track our calls, pull up information about the customer and track the customer's shipping for closes.  There is a lag time to seeing how a customer is shipping, we have to wait 1-2 days to get pricing approved for them, etc.  And after we bring on an account and grow it, we then have to give it to the field sales reps who usually have not done a single thing to work the account.  Any objections will be answered with:  "It's the right thing for the customer."   Everyone in sales knows this is an untruth.   The other thing about field sales is FedEx seems to have a preference for hiring outside for field and had no problem hiring 70 layed off DHL reps which took promotional opportunities away from internal employees.    Speaking of promotional opportunities, 
promotional opportunities are largely dependent on the relationship with your manager.  So know what to kiss and when.

review_title: Solid company, for a middle of the road job.
pros: Easy to move around to different positions.  A job you don't have to worry about losing.  Most people have been around for a long time.  Management is usually hired from within.
cons: Difficult to get pay raises or any significant salary bumps.  Not a big push to excel.  Some people have been there for long time and stopped doing work a long time ago.

review_title: Disappointed. Stuck in a rut. I am willing to take a pay cut to get out
pros:
1. Company has a good reputation
2. Good work areas with large cubicles
3. Competitive salaries and benefits
4. Cost of living is low in Memphis
5. They advocate work life balance but it really depends on your manager
6. Discounts on many things all over the city and elsewhere
cons:
1. Too much upper management. Too many layers of management
2. Not many career paths. They don't move people around very much. You can get stuck in the same department for years and years. 
3. Lower and middle managers are on average not very competent leaders
4. Politics politics politics
5. Very bureaucratic. You have to go through so much red tape to get anything done. There is a convoluted process for everything. 
6. The various operating companies and regions function as different companies sometimes with their own rules and processes
7. Those awful acronyms that don't make any sense
8. Performance reviews that are very subjective and the manager's word is final

review_title: After 20 years.....things have changed at Fedex.
job_title: Ramp Transport Driver in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Decent salary....good benefits. tuition reinbursment
cons: Incompotent Management,, constant feeling that no matter how hard you work you can always do more....no one is ever satisfied in management....the more you do the more you are expected to do, while others slide without being addressed

pros: The company is very good in providing employees with a work-life balance. FedEx is also pretty competitive when it comes to regional salaries go, but on a national scale, they might not be very well-paying.
cons: Career advancement at FedEx is not very easy. There's a lot of the "good old boy" mentality, where you have to know someone, OR you have to meet a certain quota to get ahead.

review_title: I have no idea who voted FedEx a best place to work, must have been 1k entries from the CEO
pros: There are only a few good things about FedEx; good work life balance; good health care plan. Other people who don't know will think it looks good on your resume.
cons: Management is incompetent to say the least, basic operations are beyond them. They have no ability to grow the business they only obtain business by means of customers who only know their name. They spent millions of dollars to change the colors of their logos, however their OS is from 1992.

review_title: It is a stable, conservative corporation with good benefits for it's employees.
pros: Fedex employees can be proud of the great worldwide reputation for delivering excellent service.  A hard working person begin as dockworker and later become a driver if desired. Then that person can get promoted into management positions within the operations department.
cons: Upward mobility may be limited if the employee is not in operations.  Even though there are opportunities in different departments, the main service FedEx provides is getting an item from one location and delivering it to another.

review_title: The Truckload Brokerage division needs to be deconstructed from the leadership down.
job_title: Sales Account Manager in Collierville, TN
pros: The FedEx Company name is recognized by all. Truckload Brokerage is able to hide behind the success of the other successful operating companies.
cons: No one on the FedEx Truckload Brokerage leadership team has an ounce of actual brokerage experience. Lacks knowledge and tools to source carriers, hence lacking a competitive edge in the marketplace.

review_title: Don't work here: used and abused
job_title: Senior ECO Import Agent in San Antonio, TX
pros: Schedule stability and access to benifits, your own Dusty cubicle that you can spruce up, your own half working ancient computer with smallest screen in the world, your own dirty hard chair
cons: No respect from management, you're just a rat in a cubicle, pushed to over work, favoritism, they will have you doing illegal activities, no respect for foreign shippers, disorganized, no recognition, disregard any suggestions for the office (don't even reply to your email)

pros: Stable , People oriented company. i would recommed this company to other people who wants a stable and secure workplace. Not much pressure at work
cons: Career growth is very slow. Management try to treat people, whether you are working hard or not working, the same, that demotivates people who works really hard. Management need to consider this much better

job_title: Package Handler in Grove City, OH
pros: You will never need to go to the gym again. Very physically demanding work, with decent pay. Hours are pretty flexible for the different sorts (Consisting of 3 to 4 hour shifts, or 7 to 8 for a double shift) taking place throughout the day. Most of the other workers who are tenured tend to treat you well and help where they can, surely so they can make some friends and help avoid turnover. Staff is generally kind and cares about you getting hurt, whether it be for company protection or your own well being- that can be a hit or miss depending on the manager/supervisor. Advancement is possible, although politics probably play into that for some people. Not all though.
cons: Sometimes, it seems they value quantity far more than quality. When we load trailers we sometimes get overloaded and you can easily get written up for not meeting their goals for the day. Normally, hitting the goal is handling and scanning 1 box every 7 seconds. This may not seem hard, but when the boxes coming down the chutes jam, you have to walk to the jam, break it, and hope that boxes don't spread all throughout the truck trailer. Sometimes labels are smeared and don't scan properly or at all. Little to no help most of the time, making the 1 box every 7 seconds hard at times. Management can sometimes treat you like a number, which working at a factory-like facility where you are easily replaced... Maybe that's not a con but more a norm sadly. Prepare to feel pain, whether it cuts, bruises or knots from where boxes ranging from 5 lbs. to 150 lbs. attack you.

review_title: Not as good as it once was - Becoming what it will be
pros: good pension. work environment could be ok if you have a good manager.
cons: way overworked. health insurance not as good as it should be - like obamacare silver. pay lags behind. they have gotten rid of incentive/bonus pay for professionals. lots of outsourcing. no feeling of job security.

job_title: Delivery Driver in San Antonio, TX
pros: Outstanding benefits, seasoned drivers understand new team members will require help to learn all the details to perform their duty and willingly do so no questions asked. Holiday seasons overtime is always available.  Once your route becomes second nature you become immune to the demands you do your best and that’s all you can  do.
cons: Hitting the delivery times are difficult to sustain per the system driven requirements … real life road conditions and out dated mapping is an obstacle in itself.

review_title: FedEx is a great company to work for.
pros: FedEx is a company that is a leader in the transportation Industry. FedEx offers great career advancement opportunity. Very good training and preparation for other job opportunites. Management is fair, but there tends to be a lot of gossip floating around in the inside sales offices. Travel benefits and shipping discounts are awesome. You really can't compete with FedEx when it comes to these kinds of perks.
cons: Politics and the gossip that goes around, and since the corporation is a large one the pay is not very good initially. It is a sacrifice initially for a long term career success.

pros: People Service Profit philosophy, prestigious name and well recognized company to work for. The benefits are great and the service provided to customers is second to none.
cons: As with any large company, can become a little political when looking for promotion opportunities. Although there are many great promote-from-within programs the company offers such as Aspire to Management, HR needs to do a better job of ensuring that fresh talent has a fair shot at being selected for vacancies.

pros: Tuition reimbursent, 3 week-vacation after 5 years, decent health care insurance, collaborative environment.
cons: Recently hired couriers wages are close to 10 year veterans, wage stagnation, take more than 17 years to max out, lack of employee's bargaining power when it comes to benefits and wages, lack of  performance based payment, consistent benefit-payment reduction (split-shift payment elimination, higher insurance deductibles), more responsability at work does not translate in better pay (Dangerous goods specialists and other positions don't get any pay increase).

review_title: One of the greatest companies and work cultures founded on a people service profit philosophy

review_title: Fedex Courier driver, hard work but feels good.

cons: Very difficult to find an open full time position. When the jobs do come available, there's usually several people with more time in than you bidding.

job_title: DG Agent in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Even at Part Time- you have the ability to work additional hours through the Ahead system and often come close to or past a 40 hour week. Especially during Peak. If your willing to work they are willing to pay. If you work a day that's not on your schedule it's time 1/2.
cons: Very difficult to find an open full time position. When the jobs do come available, there's usually several people with more time in than you bidding.

pros: Fast paced amd my co-workers and bosses are easy to get along with.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Torrance, CA
pros:

If your experienced in the field and your not a current employee this is a good job to work for they will pay you your worth.
cons:
Poor leadership, no personal growth, a lot of office politics and open favortism.

pros:

Stable Company
Growth Opportunities

would be great to have more opportunities to shadow and learn about other departments for tea members who maybe unsure about their next career steps
slow to resolve IT issues, even though we have an internal IT team it often takes a long time to resolve simple IT issues

pros: Trained and worked from home. Set up was very easy including free equipment and utilities. Tons of company perks and good benefits.
cons: You are trained to basically lie to customers. Training is not long enough and after training you are just thrown in not fully prepared. Not very flexible with employee schedules, your stuck in the shift you were hired in for at least a year. The company doesn't seem to care about the customers as much as being the best in the market. Dealing with unhappy customers 24/7 trumps the perks. I had to quit just to be happy again.

pros: There really isn't a single one.
cons: Your manager who has way too much discretion will always be on your butt about working faster, even if you're drenched in sweat. The managers don't care, their job is to watch you work your butt off all day while they do nothing. Heck you can be running at 350 Packages per Hour and your manager will still be on you like a cheap suit. Not all managers are like this. Some are alright, but most are college dropouts or in a management position due to nepotism and favoritism. Don't work here unless you need money like RIGHT NOW.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Raleigh, NC
pros: FedEx has good benefits and is diverse - at least in some larger markets.  There is a lot of opportunity for training and continuing your education, etc.
cons: Job promotion - it is all politics ... poor performers are often promoted.  People get promoted because they go to church with someone, I'm not kidding.  So, unless you go to church with a VP - forget it - you won't get the job.

pros: Relaxed culture, work stays at the office. As long as you show up to work and don't mess up too badly you will get promoted when it is your "turn."
cons: monotonous work, nothing exciting to do unless you are a VP. It does not really matter if you are hard working or talented, you will end up waiting in line behind other, less competent, employees simply because they have been working at FedEx longer. I was just an intern observing the office, but it seemed like a frustrating place to work.

review_title: I enjoyed my 20 years at FedEx, the best service in the industry, without question.
pros: The salaries and benefits are adequate and job security is a given as long as you meet performance and productivity expectations, as well as not violating the Acceptable Contact Policies. In sales/sales management you get to work with various different companies/industries in different locations around the world. Also, the ability to be friends and work with mentors who are truly experts in their respective fields.
cons: Compensation, you will be provided a fair wage, however you will never get wealthy, yet upper level management makes a tremendous amount of money when compared to front line management. Major compensation issues in regard to being equally fair accross the board. The culture has changed, before the "merger" with RPS, the company truly put the employees first and followed the policy  of treat your employees well, and in turn your employees will provide the best possible service to our customers, and therefore profitability will follow. The policy worked for years but when the merger happened the employees were no longer treated with respect and were treated as if they were a liability that could be replaced on a whim. Also management by intimidation has become the culture of the day, with the new performance review system and the sales professionals and sales manager no longer have the empowerment to make decisions in which they could have made prior to 1999, and no longer able to run their perticular district or region as they wanted to. In the beginning the mantra was to run each territory/district/ region as it was the sales persons personal business, that is no longer an option.

review_title: Not as good of a company as everyone may think.
pros: Opportunity to learn a lot about printing and shipping.
cons: Promotions(they rarely promote within the company, if you are lucky enough to do so, it takes a loooong time, and barely a raise), raises suck, no company perks besides 75% off Express shipments, if you are "full time" you will be given about 30 hours(don't expect 40), the training SUCKS terribly...be prepared to learn EVERYTHING on your own as it happens.

job_title: Programmer Analyst Advisor in Dallas, TX
pros: FedEx cares about their people and they make every effort to come through even in tough times.  FedEx is a large company with lots of opportunities and awesome brand recognition.  Amazing focus on work life balance!
cons: Salaries are slightly lower than market but the job security and people service profit lifestyle really makes up for that!  Satellite locations may have lesser opportunities.

job_title: Could BE A Great Place to Work If Some Changes Are Made Soon in Macon, GA
pros: I like my job and try as much as possible to adavnce.  I am the spotter but what is that really saying? I learn how to do the job.  I can scan trucks, split 100,200 & 300 belts.  I finally got Insurance.  This is the first time that I wanted to work for somebody else in about 20 years.  I like the shift that I work.  It enable be to do construction work in the daytime.  I am very use to working hard and I know how to make my job work smoother.  I am a problem solver.  I apply my work ethics to Fedex and share what ever I can with who is willing to listen.  I hope one day to be come a manager
cons:
One of the mangers is a slave driver. He brings his personal problems to work with him.  Then he unloads it on the crew members.  Don't get him cross on that day when he comes in,in a bad mood.  That was yesterday.  Don't really know what I did.  He is like a hound dog just got a peice of your clothes given to him.  And everybody knows that he is out to get you.  
There are only three white people working on our shift.  It is very hard work.

pros: FedEx was a great company to work for, plenty of resources available to compensate their employees.  A lot is expected of you physically to work in this position, and it all needs to be done quickly, but you are rewarded for your hard work.
